metadata.sermon_title: Advent Begins in the Dark: Salisbury
metadata.sermon_start_end: Every year, Advent begins in the dark. Today’s reading from the prophet Isaiah sets the stage. “In our sins we have been a long time, and shall we be saved? We have all become like one who is unclean, and all our righteous deeds are like a polluted garment. [...] To be a Christian is, yes, to live in solidarity every day of our lives with those who sit in darkness and in the shadow of death, but also to live most truly in the unshakeable hope of those who expect the dawn. “I don’t dislike God. I’m not mad at him. I’m afraid of him.” And the angel said unto them, Fear not. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon utilizes multiple texts (Isaiah, Psalms, Mark) rather than a single specific pericope. It treats 'Advent' as a thematic keyword rather than recreating one specific Bible passage into a new, current word. It leans toward a 'speech about the gospel' rather than an exposition of what THIS text says that can be found nowhere else.
quotes: Today’s reading from the prophet Isaiah sets the stage.
The Biblical readings are set for us, but they are filled out each year by contemporary voices
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one specific pericope (e.g., Isaiah 64) and isolate its unique theological contribution—such as the specific imagery of the 'polluted garment'—rather than merging it into a general Advent mood.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of Hebrew or Greek study, nor an exploration of the original context of the Babylonian exile (Isaiah) or the first-century crisis (Mark). The text is used as a mirror for the preacher's 'mood' rather than being expounded from its own historical-theological horizon.
quotes: Isaiah depicts the silence and absence of God in today’s reading
the young Church told and retold a story to herself
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: The preacher must address what the 'hiding of the face' meant specifically for Israel in exile to prevent the text from becoming a mere illustration for modern psychological states.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest element. It avoids generalities by citing specific, gritty examples: the starvation of children in Belgium, Pan Am Flight 103, and the Susan Smith trial. It effectively identifies the 'zeitgeist' of sentimentalism vs. reality.
quotes: a funeral was held in Belgium for one of the little girls who was slowly and systematically starved to death
Americans now spend several hundred million dollars a year on scented candles
During the trial of Susan Smith, who drowned her little boys
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the specific mechanics of the text rather than from a collection of 'Advent texts' curated by the preacher.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Exposition and application are mixed, but because the 'exposition' is thin, the movement is more between 'thematic reflection' and 'contemporary anecdote.' The hearer is drawn into a mood, but not necessarily into the internal logic of the Scripture passage.
quotes: Advent teaches us to delay Christmas in order to experience it truly
I collect Advent texts. The Biblical readings are set for us, but they are filled out each year by contemporary voices
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Use the specific grammar of the Bible passage to 'expound' the contemporary situation, rather than using contemporary situations to explain the 'mood' of the Bible.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon dwells deeply and correctly on 'misery' (darkness, sin, wrath). It avoids 'soft' misery. Redemption is presented as coming from 'somewhere else' (grace). Gratitude is seen in the 'armor of light' and service to others.
quotes: It requires courage to look into the heart of darkness, especially when we are afraid we might see ourselves there.
The human race cannot expect to receive any lasting comfort from this world. It must come from somewhere else
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'misery' of the contemporary examples back to the 'misery before God' (sin) as Isaiah does, to avoid purely secular tragedy.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon touches on the 'two ways' through the lens of the doorkeeper's watchfulness and the fear of God. It acknowledges the possibility of being lost in time (the void) and eternity (judgment). However, the call to decision is somewhat muted by the focus on 'mood.'
quotes: It is about the Second Coming, 'in glory, to judge the quick and the dead.'
lest he come suddenly and find you asleep.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Strengthen the 'narrow way' as a concrete call to the hearer's will, rather than just a 'solidarity with those in darkness.'

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos, specifically as the 'wounded surgeon' and the one who identifies with the lost. The doctrine of the two natures is implied in the 'burst of transcendent power' entering the human sphere. However, Christ often feels like an answer to a psychological 'Advent question' rather than the Lord of the text.
quotes: Until he comes again, he is hidden among us, 'the wounded surgeon,' the bleeding Victim
The news of God’s entrance into the world ruled by sin and death is nothing less than astounding.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make Christ's divinity and lordship more explicit as the ground of hope, rather than just his solidarity in suffering.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 16.5 minutes, the sermon falls short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. While it has thematic depth, it lacks the 'breadth' of systematic exposition required to sustain a 20-minute movement.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical portion (Thesis 2) to provide the necessary breadth that allows the depth of the text to resonate.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily in its formal definition: it is a thematic speech about 'Advent' rather than an exposition of a specific Bible passage. It lacks rigorous exegesis and fails the 20-minute length requirement. However, it succeeds in its concrete application and its refusal of 'cheap comfort,' taking the 'misery' of the human condition with appropriate theological seriousness.
strengths: Concrete application that avoids 'general truths' by using specific, harrowing contemporary examples.
Strong emphasis on the 'misery' aspect of the three parts, refusing to sentimentalize the Gospel.
Effective use of the 'zeitgeist' to critique modern spiritual illusions (e.g., scented candles).
weaknesses: Lack of specific pericope focus; the sermon is a mosaic of texts and quotes.
Absence of original language study or historical-theological context (Exegesis).
Insufficient length to achieve the 'breadth' required for true homiletic depth.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an effective religious address, but according to Dekker’s strict formal definition, it is not yet a 'sermon' because it lacks specific exposition of a single passage and the necessary breadth of time.
